company.why: Dead deals aren't really dead—they're just sleeping. Budget freed up? New decision-maker? Your competitor dropped the ball? These 'lost' opps have 3x higher close rates than cold outreach because the relationship already exists. The key: give them a NEW reason to say yes (new feature, case study, pricing). Strike before your competition does.

company.example: 6-month old opportunity → New feature launched → Re-engage with value add

company.why: One person opening your email 8 times? That's not obsession—it's your champion forwarding it around. This is buying committee activation in real-time. Multiple opens = multiple stakeholders = deal momentum. Smart move: Ask who else should be in the conversation and offer a team demo. This is your window to expand.
company.template: [FirstName], I see there's growing interest in [solution]. Who else should I loop in to discuss how this helps [objective]?
company.example: Email opened 8 times → Multiple stakeholders → Expand conversation

company.why: Regulations create urgency like nothing else. GDPR scared companies into spending millions overnight. New laws = mandatory budgets + executive attention + shortened sales cycles. Position your solution as the compliance path of least resistance. Pro tip: Get ahead of the regulation news cycle and you'll own the category.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], with [new regulation] taking effect, companies in [industry] need to adapt. Here's how [solution] ensures compliance...
company.example: GDPR launch → Privacy compliance tools → Massive demand spike

Companies scramble to adapt or risk losing their distribution. Your timing window is 30-90 days max. Move fast, educate hard, close deals before the panic subsides.
company.template: [FirstName], [Platform] just changed [policy]. Companies using [old method] are at risk. Here's how to adapt...
company.example: Gmail sender requirements → Email deliverability tools → Urgent need

company.why: Sunset announcements are goldmines. Thousands of users suddenly need a new home, and they're already trained on the workflow. No cold outreach needed—they're actively searching. The winners? Companies who have comparison pages ready, fast migration support, and special 'refugee' pricing. Build the welcome mat before they arrive.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], I know you were using [competitor]. With their recent [acquisition/closure], we're helping former users transition to [solution].
company.example: Competitor acquired → Users need alternative → Perfect timing for outreach

The key: don't sell expansion, sell consolidation. 'Do more with less' beats 'do more' every time during RIFs. Wrong move: ignoring them. Right move: tailored efficiency pitch.
company.template: [FirstName], restructuring often means doing more with less. [Solution] helps automate [function] without adding headcount.
company.example: Marketing layoffs → Marketing automation tools → Efficiency play

company.why: G2 rants and Reddit complaints are buying signals in disguise. Someone frustrated enough to write a review is frustrated enough to switch. Track competitor reviews, filter for your ICP, and reach out with: 'Saw your feedback on [Tool]. We built [Your Product] specifically to solve that pain.' Timing beats cold calling 10:1.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], I noticed concerns about [competitor]'s [limitation]. We built [solution] specifically to address this. Here's how...
company.example: Negative review of competitor → Your product solves that issue → Opportunistic outreach

company.why: They filled out 80% of your demo form and bounced? That's not rejection—that's hesitation. Something scared them off (too many fields, unclear pricing, wrong timing). A simple 'Hey, noticed you stopped by—what can I clarify?' email converts 20-30% of these into meetings. Low-hanging fruit hiding in your analytics.
company.template: [FirstName], I noticed you started exploring [solution] but didn't finish. What questions can I answer to help you evaluate?
company.example: Demo form 80% complete → Follow-up within 1 hour → Higher completion rate

If your product solves that SPECIFIC pain, you're not interrupting—you're rescuing. Use tools like lemlist Intent to catch these moments and position yourself as the immediate fix.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], I saw you reached out about [issue]. This is exactly what [solution] was designed to solve. Quick call?
company.example: Support ticket about integration → Your product has that integration → Sales opportunity

company.why: PR disasters force change. A data breach makes security tools essential overnight. Exec scandal? Time for new leadership. Bad earnings? Cost-cutting tools get greenlit. Approach with empathy, not opportunism: 'Given recent events, here's how [Solution] helps companies rebuild trust.' Crisis = catalyst for decisions that took months.
company.template: [FirstName], challenging times often require new approaches. [Solution] helps companies in similar situations by [benefit].
company.example: Data breach coverage → Security solutions → Urgent need to rebuild trust

company.why: When companies hire aggressively, they need tools to scale. New employees = new seats, new workflows, new infrastructure. Hiring 50 SDRs? They need your sales engagement platform. Hiring 20 engineers? They need your dev tools. Track LinkedIn job postings and connect growth to your tool category. Expansion mode is buying mode.
company.template: [FirstName], I saw you're hiring [X] [positions]. This typically signals [challenge]. Here's how [solution] helps scale...
company.example: Hiring 10 SDRs → Sales engagement platform → Scaling infrastructure need

company.why: Email clicks, webinar signups, guide downloads—these aren't vanity metrics, they're intent signals. Someone consuming multiple pieces of your content is self-educating and building internal buy-in. The mistake: treating all content equally. High-intent content (pricing guides, comparison pages) beats top-of-funnel (blog posts) by 10x. Route accordingly.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], I noticed you've been reading about [topic]. Thought you'd find [resource] helpful as you evaluate [solution].
company.example: Downloaded 3 whitepapers → High interest → Nurture with personal outreach

company.why: Fresh funding = spending mode... for about 6 months. After that, it's back to scrutiny. The sweet spot: 30-90 days post-announcement when they're hiring, scaling infrastructure, and building the 'growth stack.' Be in their inbox before their hiring plan is finalized. Early conversations = embedded in the roadmap.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], congrats on the [round]! As you scale [function], [solution] helps companies at your stage by [benefit].
company.example: Series B $20M → Scaling sales team → CRM/sales tools opportunity

Public companies broadcast their roadmap quarterly—and smart sellers listen. Find the pain points mentioned 3+ times and pitch solutions to those EXACT challenges. This is insider trading for sales.
company.template: [FirstName], I noticed [initiative] mentioned in your recent earnings call. [Solution] helps companies execute on this by...
company.example: Earnings call mentions AI investment → AI tools → Relevant timing

company.why: Webinar attendees who stay past 30 minutes are evaluating solutions, not just learning. They're comparing, taking notes, and potentially building a business case. Follow up within 24 hours while your brand is fresh: 'Loved seeing you at [Webinar]. What part resonated most?' You're not selling—you're continuing the conversation.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], thanks for joining our webinar on [topic]. What questions can I answer as you evaluate [solution]?
company.example: Attended product webinar → Asked questions → High intent for demo

company.signal: New leadership recently hired (CEO, C-level, board)
company.why: New execs bring new budgets, new vendors, and 90-day mandates to 'make an impact.' They haven't been captured by the status quo yet. The first 100 days are your window—they're reworking the stack, challenging old contracts, and proving their worth. Your pitch: 'You weren't here for the old decision. Here's the modern approach.'
company.template: Hi [FirstName], congrats on the new [C-level] hire! New leadership often means new initiatives. Here's how [solution] supports...
company.example: New CTO hired → Infrastructure/dev tools → 100-day plan opportunity

Position yourself as the unified solution before the integration team standardizes on your competitor. Bonus: acquiring companies often enforce their stack on acquired companies. Know who's the buyer.
company.template: [FirstName], integrating [acquired company] will require [challenge]. [Solution] helps M&A teams by [benefit].
company.example: Acquired competitor → Integration tools → System consolidation need

company.why: Job postings are budget approvals in disguise. Hiring a 'Head of Sales Ops'? They need CRM, engagement, and analytics tools. Posting for a 'Security Engineer'? Someone just allocated $500K for infosec. Match your ICP roles to your product category and reach out BEFORE they start. Be part of the onboarding plan.
company.template: [FirstName], I saw you're hiring a [position]. This role typically needs [tool/solution]. Happy to show how [solution] helps...
company.example: Hiring Data Engineer → Data infrastructure tools → Technical buyer identified

company.why: Awards = validation = marketing moments. Companies love promoting wins, and that means stakeholder attention is high. 'Congrats on [Award]—we work with [Similar Winner] to...' instantly leverages social proof. Plus, award-winning companies often get budget boosts to 'maintain momentum.' Strike while morale and attention are high.
company.template: Congrats on [award], [FirstName]! Companies at your level often need [solution] for [challenge]. Worth discussing?
company.example: Forbes Cloud 100 → Enterprise-grade solutions → Scale conversation

Happy customers have loose budgets and high trust. Use success stories as expansion triggers, not just marketing collateral.
company.template: Hi [FirstName], we just published a case study with [similar company] who achieved [results]. Thought you'd find it relevant given [context].
company.example: Case study with competitor → Share results → FOMO trigger

They're Googling 'best [tool] for Europe' and your SEO better be ready. Offer 'expansion packages' and position yourself as the regional expert. First mover wins.
company.template: [FirstName], expanding to [region] brings [challenges]. Here's how [solution] helps companies scale internationally...
company.example: Expanding to EU → GDPR compliance tools → Regulatory requirement

Don't just say 'your trial ends Friday'—say 'your trial ends Friday, and here's what you'll lose access to.' Paint the pain of going back to the old way. Fear of loss > promise of gain.

company.example: Black Friday offer → 48-hour urgency → Limited-time conversion

If they're still there but the email changed, it's a re-engagement opportunity: 'Saw your email bounced. Still the right contact for [Topic]?' Small signal, big opportunity.

company.example: Champion email bounces → Find replacement on LinkedIn → New opportunity

People are more open to conversations during positive moments. It's warm outreach disguised as celebration. Plus, promotions = new budgets.

company.example: 5-year work anniversary → Congrats + relevant offer → Relationship building

company.example: Competitor case study → Share with their competition → Competitive trigger

person.example: New VP of Sales hired → Sales tools → First 90 days budget

person.example: Manager promoted to Director → Bigger budget + scope → Upsell opportunity

product.template: [FirstName], I'm sorry we didn't meet expectations. Can we schedule 30 min to understand what went wrong and how to fix it?
product.example: NPS score of 3 → Churn risk → Executive intervention

community.why: Community engagement shows thought leadership and willingness to help others - perfect champion profile.
community.template: [FirstName], love your contributions in [community]! Your insight on [topic] was spot-on. We help companies with [related challenge]...
community.example: 10+ Slack group answers → Community leader → Champion potential

community.why: Questions in communities are explicit pain points looking for solutions.
community.template: Hi [FirstName], saw your question in [community] about [problem]. We actually built [solution] specifically for this. Happy to show you...
community.example: Asked about integrations → Solution has that → Perfect product-market fit

community.why: Public complaints or frustrations are buying signals in disguise.
community.template: [FirstName], I saw you mention [pain point] in [forum]. We've helped companies solve this exact issue with [solution]...
community.example: Reddit post complaining about tool → Alternative solution → Frustrated buyer

community.why: Upvoting features shows what they need but don't have in current tools.
community.template: Hi [FirstName], I see [feature] matters to you. [Solution] has this built-in. Want to see how it works?
community.example: Upvoted 'better reporting' → Product has advanced analytics → Feature-led pitch

community.why: Joining competitor communities shows active evaluation or current usage with potential pain points.
community.template: [FirstName], saw you joined [competitor community]. If you ever need a comparison or alternative, [solution] offers [differentiation]...
community.example: Joined HubSpot community → HubSpot user → Competitive intel

community.why: Sharing competitor content shows awareness of category and research behavior.
community.template: [FirstName], saw you shared [competitor]'s content on [topic]. We do [topic] differently by [unique approach]. Interested in comparing?
community.example: Shared Gong content → Sales tech interested → Competitor awareness

community.why: Blog comments show active research and thought process on relevant topics.
community.template: Hi [FirstName], great comment on [blog post] about [topic]. This aligns with [solution]'s approach. Want to discuss?
community.example: Commented on 'Best CRMs 2024' → CRM evaluation → Active buyer

community.why: Reviews show first-hand experience and often reveal what they wish the product had.
community.template: [FirstName], I read your [competitor] review. You mentioned wanting [feature they lack]. [Solution] has this built-in. Demo?
community.example: Reviewed competitor, wanted better UX → Product has better UX → Switching opportunity

community.why: Conference attendance shows heavy investment in category and potential expansion needs.
community.template: [FirstName], how was [competitor conference]? As you think about [topic from event], [solution] offers [complementary value]...
community.example: Attended Salesforce Dreamforce → Ecosystem partner → Complementary tool pitch

community.why: Social engagement patterns reveal interests, priorities, and peer influences.
community.template: [FirstName], saw you shared [influencer]'s take on [topic]. We think about this similarly at [company]. Here's our approach...
community.example: Retweeted Jason Lemkin on SaaS metrics → SaaS tool buyer → Thought leadership connection

community.why: Newsletter subscriptions show ongoing interest in category and competitor monitoring.
community.template: Hi [FirstName], I see you follow [competitor content]. We publish similar insights on [topic]. Want our perspective?
community.example: Subscribed to Drift newsletter → Conversational marketing → Category interest

community.why: Social follows indicate awareness and potential evaluation of alternatives.
community.template: [FirstName], I notice you follow [competitor]. If you're evaluating [category], [solution] differentiates by [unique value]...
community.example: Followed 3 competitors → Active research → Comparison opportunity

community.why: Content downloads from competitors show active problem-solving and solution research.
community.template: Hi [FirstName], saw you're researching [topic]. Our [competing resource] offers a different take. Want both perspectives?
community.example: Downloaded 'Sales Playbook' from competitor → Sales tools → Alternative option

community.why: Webinar participation shows high engagement and active evaluation of solutions.
community.template: [FirstName], how was [competitor]'s webinar on [topic]? We approach [topic] differently by [approach]. Want to compare?
community.example: Attended Zoom webinar → Video conferencing evaluation → Alternative demo

community.why: Being tagged or mentioned shows you're relevant to their network and challenges.
community.template: [FirstName], thanks for the mention in your discussion about [topic]! Happy to expand on [solution]'s approach to this...
community.example: Tagged in LinkedIn discussion → Relevant to their challenge → Inbound interest

event.why: Event registration shows active engagement in industry and openness to conversations.
event.template: [FirstName], see you at [event]! Want to grab coffee and discuss [relevant topic]?
event.example: Registered for SaaStr → Schedule meeting → In-person connection

event.why: Speakers are influential and highly engaged - perfect prospects or champions.
event.template: [FirstName], excited for your [event] talk on [topic]! This aligns with [solution]. Can we connect at the event?
event.example: Speaking at conference → Attend talk → VIP meeting setup

event.why: Event sponsorship shows budget, marketing initiatives, and brand-building focus.
event.template: [FirstName], congrats on sponsoring [event]! That level of investment shows you're serious about [market]. Let's discuss how [solution] supports this...
event.example: Event sponsor → Marketing budget → Brand awareness tools

event.why: Hosting events signals thought leadership positioning and growth initiatives.
event.template: [FirstName], your [event] on [topic] looks great! Companies scaling events often need [solution] for [challenge]. Interested?
event.example: Hosting webinar series → Event tech/marketing tools → Operational need

event.why: Trade show presence indicates active selling, partner ecosystem development, or market expansion.
event.template: [FirstName], I'll be at [tradeshow] too! Want to stop by and see [solution] in action? Booth [number].
event.example: Exhibiting at conference → Visit their booth → Relationship building
